title: Smart link detection isn't aware of certain utf8 characters
body:
Typing `Hello there！couchers.org` will give this: Hello [there！couchers.org](https://there！couchers.org)

This is because ！ is a full-width exclamation mark, a UTF-8 character which is common in some languages (ie. Chinese) to end sentences with no space. We need to detect these characters in our link-creation regex

title: Cicking "submit" without selecting yes/no/maybe on signup flow is possible
body:
When signing up, you can click "submit" on the "have your say" page without selecting yes/no/maybe. This should not be possible. While users should be able to skip providing feedback, they should at least be forced to select yes/no/maybe (and if they select yes or maybe, provide additional information as a requirement).

This will prevent users who are frustrated when they click the button prematurely and, more importantly, will help provide the recruiting team with more relevant information (and hopefully more volunteers!)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/79384268/148679044-3ec861cd-f7ac-47b1-9150-5a7fa632b605.png)

title: fix: create/edit event form from overflowing on mobile screens
body:
The problem seems to be a grid "gotcha", where "1fr" really means
minmax(auto, 1fr), which means it's possible that the element in the
grid's min-width is larger than the width of the grid itself. I.e. auto
is greater than 1fr. This means the grid column can't shrink below that
size.

Setting min-width to 0 with minmax(0, 1fr) at the grid level allows the
grid column to shrink to fit to the width of the container, as 1fr is
guaranteed to be the max value of the two.
https://css-tricks.com/preventing-a-grid-blowout/

title: ListEventAttendees doesn't always return the current user correctly even when they are attending an event

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
Here are some rough reproduction steps:
1. Create an event
2. Transfer the event to a community (although this step probably not necessarily, only needed for it to show up in UI/`ListEvents` from `communities.proto`
3. Change the current user's attendance state to "not going" (with `SetEventAttendance`)
4. Change the current user's attendance state to "going" again

**Expected behaviour**
`ListEventAttendees` should return the current user's ID

**Actual/current behaviour**
`ListEventAttendees` returns another user's ID. This ID seems to be determined from the row's auto increment ID in `event_occurence_attendees` in the database

Basically can't release the event feature until this is fixed...

Other notes: I suspect `ListEventOrganizers` and `ListEventSubscribers` could also have this same problem, so probably worth double checking that too...

title: The local development setup - Postgres Error - UndefinedObject

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
I am following the `app/readme.md` document to set up this application on my local computer to do some development on it. However, in the `Launch the backend with docker-compose` part, I got the following error. (I use Macbook)

`sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (psycopg2.errors.UndefinedObject) type geometry`

I managed to solve the issue by applying the following steps.

1 - Manually get the CLI of the `app_postgres_1` from Docker.
2 - Run `psql postgres -c "CREATE EXTENSION postgis" -U postgres` command.

I think this `postgis` extension is missing initially.  This is a quick fix. I think this is not a good solution overall. The error shouldn't happen in the first place.

title: gRPC interceptors don't work with gRPC-Web Devtools
body:
This means that the unathenticated error handler doesn't run correctly, so for example you won't be kicked out if the backend suddenly jails your or logs you out (e.g. due to ToS version updating).

This works correctly in the prod build though because we disable the dev tools there.

See also https://github.com/grpc/grpc-web/issues/1012 and https://github.com/SafetyCulture/grpc-web-devtools/issues/80

title: Group chats are not updated in "real time"
body:
**Expected behaviour**
Messages in group chats should be updated in (near) real time.

**Actual behaviour**
Messages in group chats are currently not refreshed in (near) real time unless:
- The user quits the chat and go back in, or
- The user sends a message

**Other notes**
Should be fixable for now by changing the `refetchInterval` option in the `[groupChatMessages, groupChatId]` query to refetch every 2-3 second (hence "real time" in quotes). Probably should look into how grpc streams might help with this in the longer term as it'll likely be more efficient than spamming the server with this regular polling.

body:
When the user signs up, there aren't any checks on the date of birth they provide apart from it's in a valid date format that the backend can accept. This means it's possible to create a user that's just been born (since the date field defaults to today's date):

![A 0-years-old profile!](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13669362/111884202-ee99a800-89b7-11eb-98b2-8d9b8c9e2667.png)

I think it'd be good to add an additional check on this on the backend so we ensure the user signing up is at least 18?

title: Group chat view doesn't scroll to bottom when you send a new message

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Go to a group chat with enough messages such that scrolling is required

**Expected behaviour**
The message scroll view automatically scrolls down to the last message (either one you just sent or the latest message from another user)

**Actual behaviour**
The message scroll view is still stuck to the last message before you sent the message, so that you need to scroll down before you can see the new message(s).

title: Get a single friend request/relationship

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
There's currently no way to get a single friend request/relationship. I'm thinking this would be useful, for example:

-Someone sends you a friend request
-You go to their page to see who it is
-Ideally, you can reply to the request right there on their page

-Someone sends you a friend request
-You get a notification
-You reply to friend request straight from the notification (i.e. how it is on FB)

It's entirely possible this can all be done with respondfriendrequest and I'm just out of the loop?

title: Node constraints in database

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
I believe we can enforce the Node structure through a combination of postgres constraints (like exclusion constraints).

1. Nodes form a tree structure
2. The root ("World") contains all "space" (i.e. the whole globe)
3. Every node should have a parent, except the root node
4. Each child a node is contained within the parent node
5. The children of any given node can not overlap each other

title: fix: lower cache time for username2Id query
body:
Lowers the cache time to 14 days so the cache doesn't get incorrectly garbage collected due to 32-bit number overflow before - see https://github.com/tannerlinsley/react-query/issues/1646. 25 days was still just over the 2^31 ms and I think 2 weeks is still long enough tbh. 

Also increased the localStorage maxAge to the same amount, otherwise this stable cache will get removed on hydration after 24 hours (the default `maxAge` value in the `persist-localstorage` plugin) regardless of cache time's value.

title: Make `id` a required prop for the TextField component
body:
According to the [accessibility section in the docs for `TextField`](https://material-ui.com/components/text-fields/#accessibility), adding an `id` is needed for Material UI to label our text fields correctly, which is important for keeping our app accessible for screen readers.

It's quite a low hanging fruit considering the library does the hard work of doing the rest right so we should fix this some time. A good first issue for anyone looking to get started!

title: Address clean up from Nominatim
body:
In the legacy vue frontend, we stripped some parts of the address from Nominatim:

https://github.com/Couchers-org/couchers/blob/f95e212833a84d9c470e73530f78587676befc02/app/vue/src/components/EditableLocation.vue#L316-L334

This makes the display addresses a bunch nicer, so instead of:

```
Forbes Street, Macdonaldtown, Newtown, Sydney, Council of the City of Sydney, New South Wales, 2006, Australia
500, West 120th Street, Morningside Heights, Manhattan Community Board 9, Manhattan, New York County, New York, 10027, United States
```

We have:

```
Macdonaldtown, Sydney, Australia
Morningside Heights, Manhattan, New York, United States
```

title: Host requests notifications always appear on the "Hosting" tab

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
I think this is due to the count of host requests sent and received being a combined count, which was fine in the alpha as they live together. In the beta, they are split into a "hosting" and "surfing" tab, which means when you get an unread message on the "surfing" tab, the notification count still shows up under "hosting".

The API only returns this as a combined count at the moment and so there's no easy way to tell apart which are "hosting" requests and which are "surfing" requests at the moment, so that will probably need updating. Then frontend needs updating too to use these new separated counts.

title: Authentication logic is broken
body:
You can get stuck "phantom logged in" if the backend invalidates your session but the frontend doesn't. The frontend won't update the state to unauthenticated if it gets back an unauthenticated response from the server.

One way to reproduce:
1) Navigate to https://app.couchers.org and log in
2) Navigate to https://develop--frontend.preview.coucher.org and log in
3) Log out of https://app.couchers.org (this will remove the cookies)
4) Now https://develop--frontend.preview.coucher.org is phantom logged in

Possibly easier:
1) Go to https://develop--frontend.preview.coucher.org and log in
2) Remove cookies for domain api.couchers.org
3) You're now phantom logged in

title: TS issues with AuthInterceptor
body:
See error message here: https://gitlab.com/couchers/couchers/-/jobs/860814434

This is because the TS declarations are wrong for `unaryInterceptors` (they're typed as `string: string` or whatever, which is wrong). In vue we got around this with a bunch of `@ts-ignore` (+ `prettier-ignore` because the lines got too long and it started wrapping them, breaking the `ts-ignore`... a royal mess):

https://github.com/Couchers-org/couchers/blob/7cf44ae274d8affe360a781e299ddaf33cc8af5a/app/vue/src/api.ts#L17-L21

title: Chat events and chat pagination

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
Two options:

* Store chat events as messages without an author, can have some more fields for them
* Store chat events in separate table

The second causes issues: we'll have to do a union of those chat subscriptions that have messages and those that don't, then figure out how to sort them (so probably by time joined). Then that gets quite specific and annoying.

The key is that *it's anxiety inducing to try to deal with subscriptions that have no messages* due to joins. So putting chat events in the same table solves this as we can guarantee that each subscription has an event (e.g. "Aapeli joined the chat").

Storing events in the same table as messages is ugly because it requires some special handling.

To me it seems the lesser of two evils.

title: Divide API test fixtures into two

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
At the moment we have one `api_session` context manager that creates the gRPC server, then a channel, and yields this to the test client.

However, we should really have an `api` fixture that creates the gRPC server, and a context manager that manages the session (just channel).

This would probably speed up testing by a whole lot.

title: Markdown/input sanitisation

labels.name: backend
labels.description: This issue relates to the python backend

body:
Need to investigate sanitisation of user inputs.

Markdown should be supported, but we should check which features we support. E.g. we shouldn't load external images put in markdown descriptions (people could do things like add a tracking pixel that points to their site and see who's looking at their profile).

Also, I'm not sure if we do any sanitisation for general XSS/HTML in other fields. SQLAlchemy does fix SQL injection though, I believe.
